title: Income, Jobs, and Taxes
description: What does a job ACTUALLY pay? This module strips away the illusion of a salary number and teaches students to calculate what really lands in their bank account. Hourly vs salary vs commission, overtime math, W-2 vs 1099 tax implications, progressive taxation, and the hidden value of employer benefits. By the end, students can compare two job offers and make a justified recommendation.
goals: Calculate gross pay for hourly, salaried, and commission-based pay structures
Compute overtime pay using time-and-a-half and read/build weekly timesheets
Explain progressive taxation and estimate take-home pay after federal, state, and FICA taxes
Compare job offers by total compensation including salary, benefits, insurance, and retirement match
instructionalStrategy: Convert everything to the same basis for comparison: $50,000/year ÷ 2,080 hours = ~$24.04/hour. Is that more or less than $22/hour with overtime potential?
Overtime math: only hours OVER 40 get the 1.5× rate. Students consistently apply overtime to ALL hours — catch this early.
Tax basics: use the 'fill the buckets' model for progressive brackets. The #1 misconception is thinking all income is taxed at your top bracket. Simple estimate: 22-25% total for W-2.
1099 vs W-2 comparison is eye-opening: a $60,000 1099 contract vs $55,000 W-2 job — the W-2 often wins after self-employment tax and no benefits.

Benefits comparison: quantify everything in dollars. Health insurance ($6,000/year employer portion), 401(k) match (4% of $50K = $2,000), PTO (10 days = ~$1,900 for a $50K worker). The 'lower salary' job often wins.

scaffold.title: Pay Structures: Hourly, Salary, and Commission
scaffold.content: Not all jobs pay the same way, and understanding how your pay is calculated is the first step to knowing what you actually earn. Hourly workers get paid for each hour worked — straightforward multiplication. Salaried workers receive a fixed annual amount divided into pay periods. Commission-based workers earn a percentage of the sales they generate, sometimes on top of a base salary. To compare offers fairly, you need to convert everything to the same unit: either annual pay, monthly pay, or an hourly equivalent.
keyPoints: Hourly pay: Gross pay = hourly rate × hours worked. A $15/hour worker doing 40 hours/week earns $600/week before taxes.
Salary pay periods: Annual salary ÷ number of pay periods. Biweekly = 26 pay periods/year, semimonthly = 24, monthly = 12. A $52,000 salary pays $2,000 biweekly or $2,166.67 semimonthly.
Commission: Base salary + (total sales × commission rate). A 5% commission on $80,000 in sales = $4,000 in commission income.
Hourly equivalent of salary: Annual salary ÷ 2,080 hours (40 hrs/wk × 52 wks). $50,000/year = $24.04/hour.
When comparing pay structures, always convert to the same basis. Weekly, biweekly, and annual comparisons each reveal different things about cash flow and total earnings.

examples.problem: Marcus works at a warehouse earning $18.50 per hour. Last week he worked 38 hours. What was his gross pay for the week?
examples.solution:
Gross pay = hourly rate × hours worked
Gross pay = $18.50 × 38 = $703.00

Marcus earned $703.00 before any deductions.

examples.problem: Aisha accepts a salaried position paying $54,600 per year. She is paid biweekly (every two weeks). What is her gross pay per paycheck?
examples.solution:
Biweekly means 26 pay periods per year (52 weeks ÷ 2).
Gross pay per paycheck = $54,600 ÷ 26 = $2,100.00

Important distinction: If she were paid semimonthly (twice per month), there would be 24 pay periods and each check would be $54,600 ÷ 24 = $2,275.00. Same annual salary, different paycheck amounts.

examples.problem: David is a car salesperson who earns a base salary of $2,000/month plus 3% commission on all sales. In March, he sold $120,000 worth of vehicles. What was his total gross pay for March?
examples.solution:
Step 1: Calculate commission.
Commission = total sales × commission rate = $120,000 × 0.03 = $3,600

Step 2: Add base salary.
Total gross pay = base + commission = $2,000 + $3,600 = $5,600

David earned $5,600 in March. Note: In a slow month with only $40,000 in sales, his commission would be just $1,200, making total pay $3,200 — commission income varies significantly.

problems.question: Keisha works as a pharmacy technician earning $16.75 per hour. She worked 35 hours this week. What is her gross pay for the week?
hints: Use the formula: gross pay = hourly rate × hours worked
$16.75 × 35 — multiply the dollars by the hours

problems.question: Tyler earns an annual salary of $41,600. His company pays employees semimonthly (twice per month). What is Tyler's gross pay per paycheck?
hints: Semimonthly = 24 pay periods per year (2 per month × 12 months)
Divide annual salary by number of pay periods: $41,600 ÷ 24

problems.question: Jasmine works in retail and earns a base salary of $1,800/month plus 4.5% commission on her sales. In November she sold $65,000 worth of merchandise. What was her total gross pay for November?
hints: First calculate commission: $65,000 × 0.045
Then add the base salary to the commission

problems.question: A warehouse worker earns $21.00 per hour and worked 40 hours this week. What is the worker's gross pay?

Rena earns an annual salary of $63,000 and is paid monthly. What is her gross pay per paycheck? Then convert her salary to an hourly equivalent (assume 2,080 work hours per year). Round to the nearest cent.
problems.answer: Monthly gross = $5,250.00. Hourly equivalent = $30.29. Monthly: $63,000 ÷ 12 = $5,250. Hourly: $63,000 ÷ 2,080 = $30.29.

problems.question: A real estate agent earns no base salary but receives a 2.5% commission on every home sold. In one month she sold two homes: one for $280,000 and one for $415,000. What was her total gross pay for the month?

scaffold.title: Overtime Pay and Reading Timesheets
scaffold.content: Federal labor law (the Fair Labor Standards Act) requires most hourly workers to be paid overtime for any hours worked beyond 40 in a single workweek. Overtime pay is calculated at 1.5 times the regular hourly rate — commonly called 'time and a half.' The critical mistake students make is applying the overtime rate to ALL hours. Only the hours OVER 40 get the 1.5× rate; the first 40 hours are paid at the regular rate. Reading a weekly timesheet means totaling daily hours to determine if the 40-hour threshold was crossed.
keyPoints: Overtime threshold: 40 hours per week for most hourly employees under federal law.
Overtime rate: 1.5 × regular hourly rate. If regular rate is $16/hour, overtime rate is $16 × 1.5 = $24/hour.
Gross pay formula with OT: (40 × regular rate) + (overtime hours × regular rate × 1.5).
Only hours OVER 40 are overtime. A 47-hour week means 40 regular hours + 7 overtime hours — not 47 overtime hours.
Timesheets: add daily hours for the week. Watch for lunch breaks — if a shift is 8:00 AM to 4:30 PM with a 30-minute unpaid lunch, that is 8 hours worked, not 8.5.
Some states (like California) also require daily overtime for hours over 8 in a single day, but the standard federal rule uses the 40-hour weekly threshold.

examples.problem: Tomas earns $20.00 per hour as an electrician's apprentice. Last week he worked 46 hours. Calculate his gross pay for the week.
examples.solution:
Step 1: Identify regular and overtime hours.
Regular hours = 40 (the first 40 are always regular)
Overtime hours = 46 - 40 = 6 hours

Step 2: Calculate regular pay.
Regular pay = 40 × $20.00 = $800.00

Step 3: Calculate overtime pay.
Overtime rate = $20.00 × 1.5 = $30.00/hour
Overtime pay = 6 × $30.00 = $180.00

Step 4: Total gross pay.
$800.00 + $180.00 = $980.00

Common error: Applying $30/hour to all 46 hours would give $1,380 — that is incorrect.

examples.problem:
Here is Priya's timesheet for the week. She earns $17.50/hour.

Mon: 8:00 AM - 5:00 PM (30 min unpaid lunch)
Tue: 8:00 AM - 5:00 PM (30 min unpaid lunch)
Wed: 8:00 AM - 5:00 PM (30 min unpaid lunch)
Thu: 8:00 AM - 6:30 PM (30 min unpaid lunch)
Fri: 8:00 AM - 5:00 PM (30 min unpaid lunch)

Calculate her gross pay.
examples.solution:
Step 1: Calculate daily hours (subtract unpaid lunch).
Mon: 9 hrs on-site - 0.5 hr lunch = 8.5 hrs worked
Tue: 8.5 hrs
Wed: 8.5 hrs
Thu: 10.5 hrs on-site - 0.5 hr lunch = 10 hrs worked
Fri: 8.5 hrs

Step 2: Total weekly hours.
8.5 + 8.5 + 8.5 + 10 + 8.5 = 44 hours

Step 3: Split into regular and overtime.
Regular: 40 hours. Overtime: 44 - 40 = 4 hours.

Step 4: Calculate pay.
Regular pay = 40 × $17.50 = $700.00
OT rate = $17.50 × 1.5 = $26.25/hour
OT pay = 4 × $26.25 = $105.00
Gross pay = $700.00 + $105.00 = $805.00

examples.problem: Two workers both earn $22.00/hour. Worker A works exactly 40 hours every week. Worker B works 35 hours most weeks but picks up a 50-hour week once a month. Over a 4-week period where Worker B works 35, 35, 35, and 50 hours, who earns more?
examples.solution:
Worker A (4 weeks at 40 hrs):
4 × (40 × $22.00) = 4 × $880 = $3,520.00

Worker B:
Weeks 1-3 (35 hrs each): 3 × (35 × $22.00) = 3 × $770 = $2,310.00
Week 4 (50 hrs):
  Regular = 40 × $22.00 = $880.00
  OT = 10 × ($22.00 × 1.5) = 10 × $33.00 = $330.00
  Week 4 total = $1,210.00
Worker B total = $2,310 + $1,210 = $3,520.00

They earn the same amount! But Worker B worked only 155 total hours vs Worker A's 160 hours. Worker B averaged $22.71/hour across all hours thanks to overtime on that one big week.

problems.question: Sandra earns $15.00 per hour at a distribution center. She worked 44 hours last week. Calculate her gross pay.
hints: First find overtime hours: 44 - 40 = 4 overtime hours
Regular pay = 40 × $15.00. Overtime rate = $15.00 × 1.5 = $22.50. OT pay = 4 × $22.50.

problems.question:
Read this timesheet for Carlos ($19.00/hour):
Mon: 7:00 AM - 3:30 PM (30 min unpaid lunch)
Tue: 7:00 AM - 3:30 PM (30 min unpaid lunch)
Wed: 7:00 AM - 5:00 PM (30 min unpaid lunch)
Thu: 7:00 AM - 3:30 PM (30 min unpaid lunch)
Fri: 7:00 AM - 3:30 PM (30 min unpaid lunch)
What are his total hours for the week, and what is his gross pay?
hints: Calculate each day: Mon/Tue/Thu/Fri are 8.5 hrs on-site minus 0.5 hr lunch = 8 hrs. Wed is 10 hrs on-site minus 0.5 hr = 9.5 hrs.
Total = 8 + 8 + 9.5 + 8 + 8 = 41.5 hours. Overtime = 41.5 - 40 = 1.5 hours.

problems.question: An employee earns $14.00/hour and worked 52 hours in one week. What is the difference between the gross pay calculated correctly (with overtime) and the incorrect calculation of simply multiplying $14.00 × 52?
hints: Find each total, then subtract to find the difference.

problems.question: A construction worker earns $25.00/hour and worked 48 hours last week. Calculate the worker's gross pay for the week.

Here is Mia's timesheet ($16.50/hour):
Mon: 9 hours
Tue: 8 hours
Wed: 9 hours
Thu: 8 hours
Fri: 9 hours
Sat: 5 hours
What is her total hours and gross pay for the week?
Two job offers: Job A pays $18/hour with a guaranteed 45 hours per week. Job B pays $20/hour with exactly 40 hours per week. Which job pays more per week, and by how much?

scaffold.title: Tax Basics: W-2, 1099, and Progressive Taxation
scaffold.content: Understanding taxes is essential because your gross pay is never what you take home. As a W-2 employee, your employer withholds federal income tax, state income tax, and FICA taxes (Social Security at 6.2% and Medicare at 1.45%) from every paycheck. As a 1099 independent contractor, nobody withholds anything — you owe the full 15.3% self-employment tax (both halves of FICA) plus income tax, and you must pay quarterly. The U.S. uses progressive taxation: income is taxed in brackets, where each bracket only applies to the dollars within that range. Your marginal rate is the bracket your last dollar falls in; your effective rate is total tax divided by total income.
keyPoints: W-2 employee: employer withholds federal income tax, state tax, Social Security (6.2%), and Medicare (1.45%). Employer also pays a matching 6.2% + 1.45% on their side.
1099 contractor: no withholding. You pay self-employment tax of 15.3% (both halves of FICA) plus income tax. Must file quarterly estimated payments.
Progressive tax brackets (simplified): the first chunk of income is taxed at 10%, the next chunk at 12%, then 22%, and so on. NOT all income at the top rate.
Marginal tax rate: the rate on your next dollar of income. Effective tax rate: total tax paid ÷ gross income. Effective is always lower than marginal.
Quick W-2 estimate: for a typical single filer earning $40,000-$60,000, total taxes (federal + state + FICA) run roughly 22-25% of gross pay.

A $60,000 1099 contract is NOT the same as a $60,000 W-2 salary. After self-employment tax (~$9,180) and no employer benefits, the 1099 worker often nets less than a W-2 employee earning a lower salary.

examples.problem: Layla earns a W-2 salary of $48,000/year. Estimate her annual take-home pay if her total tax rate (federal + state + FICA) is approximately 23%.
examples.solution:
Step 1: Calculate total estimated taxes.
Taxes = $48,000 × 0.23 = $11,040

Step 2: Calculate take-home pay.
Take-home = $48,000 - $11,040 = $36,960/year

Step 3: Per paycheck (biweekly, 26 pay periods).
$36,960 ÷ 26 = $1,421.54 per paycheck

Her gross biweekly check is $48,000 ÷ 26 = $1,846.15, but after withholding she actually deposits about $1,421.54. That is a $424.61 difference every two weeks.

examples.problem:
Use these simplified tax brackets to calculate the federal income tax on $50,000 of taxable income:
- 10% on the first $11,000
- 12% on $11,001 to $44,725
- 22% on $44,726 to $95,375

What is the federal tax and the effective federal tax rate?
examples.solution:
Step 1: Tax each bracket separately.
Bracket 1: $11,000 × 0.10 = $1,100.00
Bracket 2: ($44,725 - $11,000) × 0.12 = $33,725 × 0.12 = $4,047.00
Bracket 3: ($50,000 - $44,725) × 0.22 = $5,275 × 0.22 = $1,160.50

Step 2: Total federal income tax.
$1,100 + $4,047 + $1,160.50 = $6,307.50

Step 3: Effective federal tax rate.
$6,307.50 ÷ $50,000 = 0.12615 = 12.6%

Key insight: The marginal rate is 22% (top bracket), but the effective rate is only 12.6%. This is why progressive taxation matters — not every dollar is taxed at 22%.

examples.problem: Compare: Jordan is offered a $60,000/year 1099 contract. His friend Malik has a $55,000/year W-2 job. Using a 23% total tax estimate for the W-2 and 15.3% self-employment tax plus 12% effective income tax for the 1099, who takes home more?
examples.solution:
Jordan (1099 at $60,000):
Self-employment tax = $60,000 × 0.153 = $9,180
Estimated income tax = $60,000 × 0.12 = $7,200
Total tax = $9,180 + $7,200 = $16,380
Take-home = $60,000 - $16,380 = $43,620

Malik (W-2 at $55,000):
Total taxes (federal + state + FICA) = $55,000 × 0.23 = $12,650
Take-home = $55,000 - $12,650 = $42,350

Jordan technically takes home $1,270 more, but Malik gets employer benefits — health insurance worth $6,000+, retirement match, and paid time off. Once you factor in benefits, Malik's total compensation package likely wins by thousands of dollars.

problems.question: Darnell earns a W-2 salary of $52,000/year. Using an estimated total tax rate of 24%, calculate his estimated annual take-home pay and his monthly take-home pay.
hints: Total taxes = $52,000 × 0.24
Take-home = gross - taxes. Monthly = annual take-home ÷ 12.

problems.question:
Using these simplified brackets, calculate the federal income tax on $38,000 of taxable income:
- 10% on the first $11,000
- 12% on $11,001 to $44,725
What is the tax amount and the effective federal rate?
hints: All $38,000 fits within the first two brackets. Bracket 1: $11,000 × 0.10. Bracket 2: ($38,000 - $11,000) × 0.12.
Effective rate = total tax ÷ $38,000.

problems.question: Alicia is a freelance graphic designer (1099 contractor) who earned $45,000 this year. Calculate her self-employment tax (15.3%). Then estimate her total tax burden if her effective income tax rate is about 14%. How much does she take home?
hints: Income tax = $45,000 × 0.14. Total tax = SE tax + income tax. Take-home = $45,000 - total tax.

problems.question: Nadia earns a W-2 salary of $44,000. Her employer withholds 22% for all taxes combined. What is her annual take-home pay, and what does she receive per biweekly paycheck (26 pay periods)?

Calculate the federal income tax on $55,000 of taxable income using these brackets:
- 10% on the first $11,000
- 12% on $11,001 to $44,725
- 22% on $44,726 to $95,375
What is the total tax and the effective rate?

Marcus is choosing between a $50,000/year W-2 job (estimated 23% total tax) and a $58,000/year 1099 contract (15.3% SE tax + estimated 13% income tax rate). Based on take-home pay alone, which option gives him more money? By how much?
problems.answer: The 1099 wins on take-home by $3,086, but lacks benefits. W-2: $50,000 × 0.77 = $38,500. 1099: SE tax = $58,000 × 0.153 = $8,874. Income tax = $58,000 × 0.13 = $7,540. Total 1099 tax = $16,414. Take-home = $58,000 - $16,414 = $41,586. Difference = $41,586 - $38,500 = $3,086. However, the W-2 job includes employer benefits (health insurance, retirement match, PTO) that could easily exceed $3,086 in value.

scaffold.title: Benefits and Total Compensation Comparison
scaffold.content: A salary number is only part of the picture. Total compensation includes everything your employer provides: base salary, health insurance, retirement contributions, paid time off, and other perks. Two jobs with different salaries can have very different total compensation packages — and the 'lower paying' job sometimes wins. To compare job offers fairly, you must convert every benefit to a dollar value and add it all up.
keyPoints: Total compensation = base salary + employer health insurance contribution + retirement match + value of PTO + other benefits.

Employer health insurance: the employer portion of premiums can be $5,000-$8,000/year for an individual plan or $12,000-$20,000/year for a family plan. This is money you would have to pay yourself without employer coverage.
401(k) or retirement match: if your employer matches 4% of your $50,000 salary, that is $2,000/year of free money — but only if you contribute at least 4% yourself.
Paid Time Off (PTO): convert to dollars. 10 PTO days for a $50,000/year worker = 10 × ($50,000 ÷ 260 work days) = 10 × $192.31 = $1,923 in paid days off.
Other benefits to quantify: life insurance, disability insurance, tuition reimbursement, commuter benefits, wellness stipends.
When comparing offers: line up every component side by side and total them. A $52,000 salary with strong benefits often beats a $60,000 salary with bare-bones or no benefits.

examples.problem:
Job A offers $55,000 salary with: employer health insurance worth $6,200/year, a 3% 401(k) match, and 12 PTO days.
Job B offers $62,000 salary with: no health insurance, no retirement match, and 5 PTO days.
Compare total compensation.
examples.solution:
Job A:
- Salary: $55,000
- Health insurance: $6,200
- 401(k) match: $55,000 × 0.03 = $1,650
- PTO value: 12 × ($55,000 ÷ 260) = 12 × $211.54 = $2,538.46
- Total compensation: $55,000 + $6,200 + $1,650 + $2,538.46 = $65,388.46

Job B:
- Salary: $62,000
- Health insurance: $0
- 401(k) match: $0
- PTO value: 5 × ($62,000 ÷ 260) = 5 × $238.46 = $1,192.31
- Total compensation: $62,000 + $0 + $0 + $1,192.31 = $63,192.31

Job A wins by $2,196.15 in total compensation despite a $7,000 lower salary. Plus, with Job B you would still need to buy your own health insurance out of pocket.

examples.problem:
Kayla receives two nursing job offers:
Hospital A: $68,000 salary, employer pays $7,500 for health insurance, 5% retirement match, 15 PTO days.
Clinic B: $72,000 salary, employer pays $4,000 for health insurance, no retirement match, 10 PTO days.
Which has better total compensation?

problems.question: Company A offers $47,000/year with employer health insurance worth $5,800/year and a 4% 401(k) match. Company B offers $53,000/year with no health insurance and no retirement match. Calculate total compensation for each (ignore PTO for this problem). Which offer has higher total compensation?
hints: Company A total = salary + health insurance + retirement match. Retirement match = $47,000 × 0.04.
Company B total = salary only (no benefits to add).

problems.question: Convert 15 PTO days to a dollar value for an employee earning $58,000/year. Assume 260 working days per year.
hints: Daily rate = annual salary ÷ 260 working days
PTO value = daily rate × number of PTO days

problems.question:
Job X: $50,000 salary, $6,000 employer health insurance, 3% 401(k) match, 10 PTO days.
Job Y: $56,000 salary, $3,500 employer health insurance, 1% 401(k) match, 8 PTO days.
Calculate full total compensation for each and determine which is the better financial offer.
hints: For each job: total = salary + health + (salary × match%) + (PTO days × daily rate). Daily rate = salary ÷ 260.

problems.question: An employee earns $46,000/year and receives 12 PTO days. The employer contributes $5,400/year for health insurance and matches 3% for retirement. What is the employee's total compensation?

Offer A: $60,000 salary, $7,200 employer health insurance, 4% retirement match, 15 PTO days.
Offer B: $70,000 salary, no employer health insurance, no retirement match, 5 PTO days.
Which offer has higher total compensation, and by how much?

Deshawn is comparing a W-2 job and a 1099 contract:
W-2 Job: $52,000 salary (23% total tax), $6,500 employer health insurance, 4% retirement match, 10 PTO days.
1099 Contract: $68,000 (15.3% SE tax + 13% income tax), no benefits.
Calculate take-home pay for the 1099 and total compensation for the W-2. Which is the better deal overall?
problems.answer: W-2 total compensation: $64,500. W-2 take-home: $40,040. 1099 take-home: $48,764. The W-2 total compensation package is worth $64,500 ($52,000 + $6,500 + $2,080 + $2,000 [from 10 × $200] = wait, let me recalculate). W-2 total comp: $52,000 + $6,500 + ($52,000 × 0.04 = $2,080) + (10 × ($52,000 ÷ 260) = 10 × $200 = $2,000) = $62,580. W-2 take-home: $52,000 × 0.77 = $40,040. 1099 take-home: $68,000 - ($68,000 × 0.153 = $10,404) - ($68,000 × 0.13 = $8,840) = $68,000 - $19,244 = $48,756. The 1099 has higher take-home by $8,716, but the W-2 benefits add $10,580 in value. When factoring in total compensation, the W-2 is the stronger deal.

answerKeys.ijt-12: Job A by $55; Job A = $855, Job B = $800
answerKeys.ijt-18: 1099 take-home wins by $3,086 ($41,586 vs $38,500) but W-2 benefits likely close the gap
answerKeys.ijt-19: Company A: $54,680; Company B: $53,000; A wins by $1,680
answerKeys.ijt-24: W-2 total compensation: $62,580; 1099 take-home: $48,756; W-2 is the better deal when benefits ($10,580) are factored in
